step_text: Measure 1.5 cups basmati rice and place in a strainer.
Rinse rice under running water until water is mostly clear.
Let rice drain for 5 minutes.
Chop onion and green chilies into small slices.
Heat a pot on medium and add 2 tbsp ghee.
Add sliced onion and chilies; sauté for 2 minutes.
Add mixed vegetables and peas; cook for 3-4 minutes.
Add drained rice and lightly stir for 1 minute.
Pour 3 cups water into the pot and stir once.
Add 1 tsp salt and combine gently.
Bring mixture to a steady boil on high heat.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and cook for 12–15 minutes. Then rest 5 minutes and fluff.
Wash rice and moong dal together until water runs clearer.
Soak for 5 minutes then drain.
Heat ghee in a pressure cooker on medium heat.
Add cumin seeds; let them crackle for a few seconds.
Add rice and dal; sauté for 1 minute.
Add turmeric, salt and 3 cups water.
Stir, close the lid and cook for 3 whistles on medium heat.
Turn off heat and allow pressure to release naturally.
Open lid, stir gently to combine.
Serve hot with a drizzle of ghee and pickle.
Spread leftover rice on a plate to remove clumps.
Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds until they pop.
Add peanuts and roast until crisp.
Add turmeric and mix quickly.
Add rice to the pan and stir gently.
Add lemon juice and salt, mix evenly.
Keep stirring for 1–2 minutes on low heat.
Turn off heat and let it rest covered briefly.
Garnish with coriander leaves if available.
Serve warm or at room temperature.
Make a soft dough with wheat flour and water; rest 10 minutes.
Boil and peel potatoes; mash smoothly.
Mix mashed potatoes with salt, coriander and mild spices.
Divide dough and stuffing into equal portions.
Roll a dough ball into a small circle, place stuffing, fold edges.
Gently roll the stuffed ball into a paratha shape.
Heat a tawa (griddle) and add a few drops of oil.
Cook paratha on both sides until golden brown.
Apply oil/ghee while cooking for crisp finish.
Serve hot with curd or pickle.
Rinse toor dal under cold water.
Pressure cook dal with water until soft (3–4 whistles).
Heat ghee in a pan and add cumin seeds.
Add chopped garlic and sauté till light brown.
Add chopped tomato and cook until soft.
Pour cooked dal into the pan; mix well.
Add salt and simmer for 5 minutes.
Prepare a tadka (ghee, cumin, garlic) and pour over dal.
Stir and simmer for another minute.
Serve hot with rice or roti.
Crumble paneer and keep aside.
Heat oil in a pan and add chopped onions.
Sauté onions until translucent.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook till soft.
Add turmeric and salt; mix.
Add crumbled paneer and stir for 2–3 minutes.
Adjust seasoning and cook until paneer is warm.
Garnish with coriander and serve hot.
Serve with roti or bread.
Store leftovers in fridge for up to 2 days.
Boil eggs, cool, peel and set aside.
Heat oil and sauté chopped onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste; cook briefly.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until mushy.
Season with salt and spices to taste.
Add a little water to make gravy and simmer 5 mins.
Make shallow slits in eggs and add to gravy.
Simmer eggs in gravy for 5–7 minutes.
Garnish with coriander and serve hot.
Serve with rice or roti.
Rinse rice and soak for 10 minutes.
Heat ghee in a pot and add cumin seeds.
Sauté cumin seeds until aromatic.
Add drained rice and stir for a minute.
Add 2 cups water and salt; mix gently.
Bring to boil, then reduce heat, cover and cook 12 minutes.
Turn off heat and rest covered for 5 minutes.
Fluff with fork and serve.
Optional: garnish with fried cashews.
Serve hot with dal or curry.
Chop tomatoes and onion roughly.
Heat butter in a pan and sauté onion until soft.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add water and salt; simmer 8–10 minutes.
Blend the mixture until smooth.
Strain soup if a smoother texture is desired.
Reheat, adjust salt, and add a dash of pepper.
Serve hot with croutons or bread.
Optional: add cream swirl for richness.
Store leftovers in fridge up to 2 days.
Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds.
When seeds pop, add curry leaves and sauté.
Add 2.5 cups water and bring to a boil.
Slowly add sooji while stirring to avoid lumps.
Add salt and mix thoroughly.
Cook on low heat for 4–5 minutes till water absorbs.
Turn off heat and cover for 2 minutes.
Fluff with a fork and serve hot.
Optional: garnish with lemon and coriander.
Serve with chutney or pickle.
Rinse poha briefly and drain; keep aside.
Heat oil and add mustard seeds; let them crackle.
Add peanuts and roast until crisp.
Add chopped onions and cook until translucent.
Add turmeric and mix well.
Add drained poha and salt; mix gently.
Cook for 1–2 minutes to heat through.
Turn off heat and add lemon juice.
Garnish with coriander and serve.
Serve warm with chai or as a snack.
Heat oil and sauté chopped onions till golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté briefly.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until mushy.
Add chole masala and mix well.
Add boiled chickpeas and 1 cup water; stir.
Simmer for 15 minutes on low heat.
Adjust salt and spices to taste.
Garnish with coriander and serve hot.
Serve with bhatura, puri or rice.
Store leftovers in fridge up to 3 days.
Heat oil in a wok on high heat.
Add mixed vegetables and stir-fry until tender.
Add cooked rice and toss well.
Add soy sauce and mix thoroughly.
Season with salt/pepper as needed.
Garnish with chopped green onion.
Serve immediately while hot.
Optional: add scrambled egg for non-veg version.
Adjust seasoning and serve.
Store leftovers separately for best texture.
Heat ghee in a pan and roast rava until aromatic.
Boil water with cardamom pods.
Slowly add rava to boiling water while stirring.
Add sugar and mix until dissolved.
Cook on low heat until sheera thickens.
Add a little ghee for shine and flavor.
Turn off heat and let it rest for a minute.
Serve warm; garnish with nuts if desired.
Store leftovers in fridge for a day.
Reheat gently before serving.
Rinse dal and cook until soft.
Mash dal slightly to desired consistency.
Heat ghee and add cumin and garlic.
Add chopped tomato and cook into a thick masala.
Combine dal with the masala and simmer.
Adjust salt and add water if needed.
Finish with a tadka (ghee + spices) poured on top.
Garnish with coriander and serve hot.
Serve with steamed rice or roti.
Store leftovers in refrigerator.
